The degradation of chlorine-containing volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) catalytic combustion technology is subject to the catalyst chlorine poisoning, which is resulted from the chlorination of active phases, even though the structural stable perovskite. The reaction between Ca species and dissociated chlorine species is demonstrated as an efficient way to inhibited chlorine poisoning of the active phase. Herein, a Ca substituted partial La prepared La0.8Ca0.2MnO3 (named as L8C2MO) perovskite was treated by 5% H2/Ar plasma driven route (the treated sample was denoted as L8C2MO-P), which was applied for the chlorobenzene oxidation removal. The integrated characterization results of XRD, XPS, HRTEM, etc. confirmed that Ca (mainly exhibited as CaCO3) was successfully exsolved from La0.8Ca0.2MnO3 and simultaneously leaved oxygen vacancies on the surficial layers. The continuous catalytic oxidation experiments illustrated that the conversion efficiency of L8C2MO was unexpectedly decreased compared with that of LaMnO3 (LMO in short) sample, while that of L8C2MO-P was nearly maintained the oxidation capacity, with approximately 12 °C of 90% chlorobenzene conversion temperature (T 90) higher than that of LMO. Importantly, the CO2 and inorganic chlorine species yields were significantly enhanced for L8C2MO and L8C2MO-P. The characteristic of used samples showed a possible chlorinated Ca species formation while the status of Mn phases was hardly changed, suggesting the exsolved Ca could inhibit the poison of Mn sites by binding with dissociative chlorine species. Additionally, oxygen vacancies that generated along with Ca exsolution process was definitely contributed to the deep oxidation of chlorobenzene. The possible reaction route was also studied by in situ DRIFTS and GCMS. The work provides a potential route as in situ growth of adjacent sites to protect active phases from chlorine poison in CVOCs catalytic oxidation process. Graphical Abstract Keywords Exsolution Plasma treatment Catalytic oxidation Chlorobenzene Adjacent dechlorinated site Data Availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Volatile organic compounds (VOCs) play a significant role as the primary pollutants that must be addressed for air pollution control. They are considered the main culprits behind photochemical pollution, ozone depletion, and the greenhouse effect. Chlorobenzene (CB) belongs to one of the toxic chlorinated volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) that can be released from various sources, such as the petroleum industry, metallurgical facilities, and solid waste incinerators [1], etc. Catalytic oxidation is indeed an appealing technology for such pollutants purification due to its robust elimination efficiency, minimal energy requirements, and straightforward installation [2,3]. Although Pt, Pd, and other noble metal-based catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic performance, they are costly and have poor thermal stability, which increases their susceptibility to chlorine poisoning. Furthermore, molecular sieve catalysts are susceptible to carbon deposition and deactivation [4]. In contrast, perovskite catalysts are characterized by their low cost and superior thermal stability, allowing them to be commonly employed in catalyzing the oxidation of CVOCs [5]. The perovskite LaMnO3 (LMO in short) exhibits better redox capabilities than other perovskite variants and has been extensively investigated [6]. However, the oxidation capacity of LMO is limited by poor mineralization and by the generation of byproducts [7]. Therefore, it is necessary to enhance the capacity for deep oxidation of LMO perovskite and reduce the generation of intermediate products [8]. The insufficient deep oxidation capability of the LMO perovskite is ascribed to the deactivation of the Mn active center due to its high susceptibility to binding with Cl [9]. With the high electron cloud density and strong electronegativity, Cl would undergo the electrophilic reactions with most metals, resulting in the formation of the metal chlorides MnClx and MnOyCl. Alkaline earth metals have been demonstrated to protect the activity of transition metals and enhance deep oxidation capabilities [10,11], which can form ionic compounds with nonmetallic elements; for instance, CaO is commonly used in industry for adsorbing Cl [3,12], which results in CaCl2. Introducing Ca into LMO may attenuate the chlorine poisoning effect on the Mn active phase. Conventionally, research on CVOC catalytic oxidation has focused on the substitution of La with partial replacement of Ca in perovskites [13]. These findings suggest that Ca substitution enhances the oxidation depth, thereby protecting the active phase and delaying poisoning of the reactive centers [14]. For instance, Ma et al. prepared the CaCO3/α-Fe2O3 catalyst and observed the intermediate products were deeply oxidized [14]. However, the substitution rate of Ca in perovskites prepared by such methods is limited, and an increase of Ca content leads to poor activity [15]. Therefore, methods for enhancing the exposure of Ca and improving its protective effect on Mn sites within the constraints of limited Ca doping are worth exploring. Plasma treatment has been proposed as a means to achieve in situ exposure of selected metals from perovskite, thereby circumventing the high energy consumption associated with conventional thermal reduction methods [16]. This approach enables defect engineering of the perovskite and the existence of additional oxygen vacancies during specific metal exposure [4]. For instance, the LCTN catalyst prepared by Khalid et al. exhibited Ca exposure and an increase in the oxygen vacancy concentration after plasma treatment [17–22]. Herein, we demonstrate the enrichment of Ca species on the surface of perovskite by plasma exsolution, which aims to increase the resistance of the catalyst to chlorine poisoning. Simultaneously, the plasma reduction process could generate oxygen vacancies. Through the synergistic effect of these two processes, the oxidation capacity of lanthanum manganese perovskite is improved. 2 Experiments 2.1 Preparation of the catalyst 2.1.1 Perovskite preparation The LaMnO3(LMO in short) and La0.8Ca0.2MnO3 (L8C2MO in short) perovskite catalysts were synthesized via a coprecipitation method [23,24]. First, the precipitant was set as 1.5 M (NH4)2CO3 solution. Then, La(NO3)3·6 H2O, Ca(NO3)2·4H2O, and Mn(NO3)2 (50 wt.%) were added to a beaker in stoichiometric amounts with a total metal concentration of 0.5 M. Then, the precipitant was dropped to the metal precursor solution with stirring until the final pH of the mixture above 9. Typically, after stirring for 6 h, the mixture was filtered and washed with ethanol and deionized water. After dried at 80 °C, the final samples were obtained by calcined in a muffle furnace for 5 h at 750 °C. 2.1.2 Exsolution by plasma To exsolve the particles, a quartz tubular reactor equipped with an inductive coil and a copper net connected to a Dielectric Barrier Discharge（DBD) power source. The certain amount of L8C2MO sample was affixed within a quartz tube using silica wool, which was then secured to a wooden frame. In this reactor, various gas reactants can be introduced. Then the sample was subsequently plasma treated in 5% H2/Ar gas for 15 min at 30 W, which was denoted as L8C2MO-P. Throughout the plasma treatment process, the sample remained unheated, ensuring that the overall sample temperature remained close to room temperature. The used LMO, L8C2MO, and L8C2MO-P samples were named as U-LMO, U-L8C2MO, and U-L8C2MO-P, respectively. 2.2 Catalytic activity evaluation The catalytic performance was tested in a fixed-bed reactor (with an inner diameter of 8 mm) at ambient pressure by adding 0.1 g of the catalyst. The reactant gas with 500 ppm CB in air was passed at a flow rate of 100 mL/min, where the weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) was approximately 60 000 mL/(g⋅h). The CB concentration was measured using a built-in flame ionization detector (FID) in a gas chromatograph (GC9890, Linghua, China), while the CO2 concentration was measured on a GC-FID equipped with a nickel conversion device. Inorganic chloride species (including HCl and Cl2) in the exhaust gas was absorbed by 0.0125 mol/L NaOH solution and then measured using the ion chromatography (AS2800, Wayeal, China). The organic byproducts of the exhaust gas were detected using the gas chromatographymass spectrometry (GCMS-QP2020 NX, Shimadzu, Japan). The conversion rate of CB (A CB), CO2 yield ( B CO 2 ), and inorganic chloride species yield (C Cl) were calculated using the following formulas: (1) A CB = [ C B ] in − [ C B ] out [ C B ] in × 100 % (2) B CO 2 = [ C O 2 ] out 6 [ C B ] in × 100 % (3) C Cl = [ C l ] out [ C B ] in × 100 % where [ C B ] in represents the concentration of CB in the incoming air and [ C B ] out represents the concentration of CB in the outgoing air. [ C O 2 ] out represents the concentration of CO2 in the exhaust gas, and [ C l ] out represents the concentration of inorganic chlorine in the exhaust gas. 2.3 Characterizations of the catalyst The structural characteristics, catalytic activity, and reaction pathways of the catalysts can be characterized using transmission electron microscopy (TEM), scanning electron microscopy (SEM), X-ray diffraction (XRD), X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS), Raman spectroscopy, electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), H2 temperature-programmed reduction (H2-TPR), O2 temperature-programmed desorption (O2-TPD), and in situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy (DRIFTS). All the information is detailed in Text S1 of the Supporting Information document. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Material characteristics 3.1.1 Structure and physical properties The X-ray diffraction (XRD) characterizations were implemented to observe the crystal structures of LMO, L8C2MO and L8C2MO-P. As shown in Fig. 1a, it was appeared that all the catalysts exhibited typical diffraction patterns of LaMnO3 (JCPDS 54–1275) at 2θ ≈ 22.76°, 32.39°, 39.98°, 46.67°, 52.46°, 58.03°, and 68.25°, indicating that all the three as-prepared samples belonged to the LaMnO3 perovskite. By the way, the diffractions of L8C2MO also closely matched those of cubic La0.8Ca0.2MnO3 (JCPDS 44–1040) [25]. Compared with those of LMO, the diffraction peaks of L8C2MO shifted to higher angles due to the partial substitution of La3+ ions by low-valence Ca2+ ions in the perovskite lattice [16], which led to the transformation of Mn3+ ions to Mn4+ ions with a smaller ionic radius, resulting in cell contraction to maintain charge balance, while the crystallization size of L8C2MO illustrated a smaller crystal size than that of LMO ( Table 1, calculated by Scherrer’s equation). Furthermore, after Ca introduced, L8C2MO did not exhibit any significant additional phases (including CaO, MnOx, or LaOx), indicating the successful substitution of Ca into the framework of LMO. After plasma treatment, a new peak corresponding to CaCO3 (JCPDS 41–1475) appeared in the spectrum of L8C2MO-P; this peak was generated from CaO upon exposure to CO2 in the atmosphere [26] due to its alkaline properties. Hence, the surface phase was present as CaCO3, demonstrating the exposure of Ca from the perovskite backbone, additionally the crystallization of L8C2MO-P revealed the smallest crystal grains among the as-synthesized samples (Table 1). In addition, compared with those of L8C2MO, the diffraction peak intensities of the plasma-treated sample L8C2MO-P decreased and shifted to lower angles, possibly due to surface amorphization and lattice expansion [27] which could be related to nanoparticle exposure and conducive to the formation of abundant oxygen vacancies [4,28]. The N2 physisorption analysis of all the materials is illustrated in Fig. 1b, which showed the typical type IV adsorption isotherms for all the samples, with an H3-type hysteresis loop of a regular ordered mesoporous structure [4]. As summarized in Table 1, the S BET and pore volume of L8C2MO were lower (16.55 m2/g and 0.38 cm3/g, respectively) compared with those of LMO (32.6 m2/g, 0.4 cm3/g), indicating that substitution with Ca ions resulted in a decrease in the porosity of the materials, as observed via XRD analysis [29]. After plasma treatment, the exposure of Ca further induced in a reduction in the surface area (11.3 m2/g, 0.37 cm3/g), which was agreed with the results of Kim et al. [18]. The SEM image showed that L8C2MO had a smooth surface, and no significant differences in particle size were observed ( Fig. 2a). In contrast, after plasma treatment, some obviously different L8C2MO-P nanoparticles emerged on the edge surface (Fig. 2b) [17]. The composition distributions were measured by energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS), as illustrated in the Supporting Information. Figure S1 and Figure S2 show the presence of Mn, La, O and Ca signals in both L8C2MO and L8C2MO-P. The dispersion of the Ca domain in L8C2MO was more homogeneous than that in L8C2MO-P. This result revealed the possible exposure of Ca species on the surface of L8C2MO-P, which agreed with the results of the XRD analyses. More obvious change in the morphology of L8C2MO-P was further studied via TEM. As shown in Fig. 2c and d, the d-spacing value of different crystals was calculated from the lattice fringes by applying inverse fast Fourier transform (IFT) image processing, illustrated the exsolved nanoparticle with a 0.18 nm lattice spacing emerged from the backbone framework after plasma reduction, which consisted of a lattice phase of the CaCO3 (2 0 2) planes (JCPDS 41–1475). Accompany with the lattice spacing of 0.39 nm, it is suggested the interplanar spacing of the La0.8Ca0.2MnO3 (0 2 0) planes (JCPDS 44–1040). Furthermore, EPR analysis (Fig. 1c) revealed that all the samples exhibited characteristic signals at a g value = 2.003, indicative of the presence of oxygen vacancies [4], with the signal intensity increasing from LMO to L8C2MO-P. The results indicated that the amount of oxygen vacancies can be readily modulated after H2/Ar gas plasma treatment. Raman spectra of the L8C2MO and L8C2MO-P samples were obtained and are displayed in Fig. 1d, amongst, L8C2MO and L8C2MO-P exhibited strong peak centered at 667 cm−1 and 643 cm−1, respectively, corresponding to the stretching vibration peak of Mn2O3 [30]. In particular, the peak of L8C2MO-P redshifts according to Hooke's law, which is attributed to the weakening of the Mn–O bond, in which plasma treatment results in more oxygen vacancies [30]. In other words, the generation of oxygen vacancies on the surface of the L8C2MO-P catalyst weakens the Mn–O bonds, and the abundant oxygen vacancies promote migration between surface oxygen (O ads) and lattice oxygen (O latt), possibly contributing to the oxidation activity for the deep oxidation of CB and the decomposition of intermediates [31]. 3.1.2 Surficial chemical state and oxygen species XPS was applied to explore the surficial composition and the status of the exsolved species. Fig. 3a displays the characteristic spectra of the respective dopant species for both L8C2MO and L8C2MO-P. The Ca 2p spectrum exhibited splitting into two peaks attributed to Ca 2p 3/2 and Ca 2p 1/2 [26]. After the exsolution treatment, the binding energy of Ca 2p 3/2 shifted towards the high-energy band (Fig. 6). In addition, each peak was deconvoluted into two doublet components: the one located at higher binding energy, generally associated with the segregated phase on the surface (Ca surf), and a lattice component (Ca latt) over the lower binding energy corresponding to the pristine perovskite phase [32]. As illustrated in Fig. 3a, L8C2MO exhibited a Ca surf/Ca latt ratio of about 0.94, which means most of Ca was sustained in the perovskite lattice. However, after plasma treatment, the ratio of Ca surf/Ca latt for L8C2MO-P increased to 1.38, indicating that the Ca ions dissolved to the surface, which was consistent with the characterization results obtained from XRD, SEM, and TEM analyses. Furthermore, O 1 s and Mn 2p core-level spectra are shown in Fig. 3b and c. In which, the O 1 s spectra of all samples can be fitted into four components, the peaks centered at binding energy of 528.9, 530.4, 531.4, and 532.6 eV are attributed to lattice oxygen (O latt), oxygen vacancies (O v), surface oxygen species (O surf), and surface hydroxyl groups/carbonate species [33], respectivly. After the substitution of Ca, the O latt content decreased from 41.23% to 39.45%, the surface O v content increased from 13.65% to 15.73%, and the O surf content increased from 21.63% to 24.99%. This indicated that the Ca introduction promoted the generation of oxygen vacancies on the sample surface, thereby enhancing the concentration of adsorbed oxygen on the catalyst surface [34]. Partial substitution of A atoms with a low-valence metal B (aliovalent substitution) will lead to the formation of oxygen vacancies, as a rare-earth element La was replaced by an alkaline-earth metal Ca, leaving behind a negative charge. To maintain the charge neutrality, an oxygen vacancy was formed by releasing lattice oxygen [35]. Similarly, after plasma treatment, the O v ratio increased from 15.73% to 17.36%, in contrast, the O latt ratio decreased from 39.45% to 22.2% (Table 1), indicating more oxygen vacancies were generated through plasma treatment, and the formation of oxygen vacancies not only due to non-stoichiometry A-site substitution, but also introduced during plasma driven under reduction conditions that accompanied with Ca exsolution [36], which was agreed with the results of EPR [37]. Moreover, the Mn 2p 3/2 spectra are accompanied by two peaks: the binding energies at approximately 642.8 and 644.4 eV can be distinguished into Mn3+ and Mn4+ species, respectively, as illustrated in Fig. 3c. The Mn4+/Mn3+ ratio of LMO was 0.94; after substituted by Ca2+, the ratio increased to 1.95. Ca cation offered only two electrons in the s, p valence complex in contrast three electrons of La. Hence, p-type or hole doping could be induced by Ca. As a result, there were two n-type or electron-doping mechanisms, which can occur and counteract the p-type doping through Ca [38]. These mechanisms were either implemented oxygen vacancies or oxidize a fraction of Mn3+ into Mn4+ [39]. It is known that the Mn3+ ↔ Mn4+ redox process is responsible for catalytic oxidation activity of the Mn-based catalyst, and the higher molar ratio of surface Mn4+/Mn3+ is beneficial for increasing the redox cycles [40,41]. However, the valence state of Mn changed after plasma treatment, with the Mn4+/Mn3+ ratio slightly decreased to 1.53, Mn cations in the Ca-rich interface region remained in the 3+ oxidation state. The exsolution phenomenon was confirmed in A-site-deficient perovskites, where oxygen vacancies were introduced during reduction, which destabilizes the perovskite structure and results in spontaneous exposure of B-site cation [42]. The mechanism of exsolution in LCMO perovskite could be expressed as point defect (Schottky-type defect) reactions as follows: (4) C a Ca + O O → V Ca ′ ′ + V O + CaO x (5) O 2 + V O + M n Mn → O * + V O + M n ∙ Mn where Ca Ca and O O are Ca and O lattice positions, respectively; V Ca ″ and V O denote to Ca and O vacancies, respectively. Based on the law of conservation of mass, the generation of a CaOx (denoted here as one of the possible CaCO3, CaO compositions) phase emerges and segregates at the grain surface and/or interface, Mn Mn is Mn lattice position (Mn4+); Mn Mn ∙ corresponds to lower oxidation state (Mn2+/Mn3+) in stoichiometric; O* represents active oxygen species such as O2 –, O–, etc. As a result, a higher Mn3+/Mn4+ ratio leads to more oxygen vacancies in the catalyst, indicating the highest surface content of oxygen vacancies over the L8C2MO-P. The average oxidation state (AOS) of surface Mn was calculated and listed in Figure S7 and Table 1, which followed the sequence as L8C2MO > LMO > L8C2MO-P. The lowest AOS value of L8C2MO-P indicates that the corresponding catalyst owns the richest oxygen defects, leading to more O ads in the catalysts [43]. 3.1.3 Redox capacity The redox properties of the catalysts were studied by H2-TPR ( Fig. 4a), where the curves of all the samples mainly consisted of 4 peaks, α, β, γ, and η, whereas the α, β and γ regions corresponded to the successive reduction of MnO2→Mn2O3→Mn3O4→MnO [30]. After the addition of Ca2+, the α peaks shifted toward higher temperatures, which was possible due to the activity of the surface Mn sites decreased as the mean oxidation state increased due to Ca substitute partial La cation on the A-site [44], which increased the reduction temperature of MnOx [45]. Concurrently, after the plasma treatment, the reduction temperature of the MnO2 crystals (α-peak) decreased, likely because the plasma treatment decreased the mean oxidation state of Mn, which may increase the overall activity of the catalysts [39]. The theoretical H2 consumption was calculated to be 0.12–0.33 mmol/g based on the reduction of Mn4+ (300–550 °C), as shown in Table 2 and Figure S6, which sequence were consistent to XPS analysis: L8C2MO > LMO > L8C2MO-P. The O2-TPD measurements were carried out to evaluate the oxygen species of the catalysts. As illustrated in Fig. 4b, the oxygen species can be divided into three parts. Amongst, the desorption peaks crossing 100–400 °C (denoted as α-O) was usually considered to be the surface adsorbed oxygen species [6]; the second one was desorbed over approximately 400–650 °C (denoted as β-O), which was assigned to the lattice oxygens near the surface [46]; and those above 650 °C (denoted as γ-O) can be classified as the lattice oxygen [11]. As depicted in Fig. 4b, the desorption peak of L8C2MO mainly situated between 300 and 600 °C, which shifted to a higher temperature region compared with LMO, indicating the partial substitution of Ca2+ in the catalyst prevented the fluidity of the surface lattice oxygen [45]. Conversely, for L8C2MO-P, the desorption of β-O shifted toward lower temperatures, confirming that the plasma treatment contained abundant oxygen vacancies [39], facilitating their activation when in contact with CB molecules. 3.2 Catalytic reactivity The catalytic performance of LMO, L8C2MO, and L8C2MO-P were measured at atmospheric conditions. With the activity continuous curves shown in Table 2 and Fig. 5a, the approximately 90% CB conversion temperature (T 90) of the LMO sample was at 325 °C. After Ca substitution, the catalytic activity slightly reduced, where T 90 of L8C2MO was presented at 350 °C. This can be explained by the decreased liquidity of the lattice oxygen species [45] and the lower mean oxide state of Mn resulting from Ca substitution [44]. After plasma treatment, L8C2MO-P exhibited catalytic activity toward CB with a T 90 at 338 °C, which was approximately 13 °C greater than that of LMO but approximately 12 °C less than that of L8C2MO. The increase in activity observed after plasma treatment was facilitated by the generation of additional surface-adsorbed oxygen [31] and the decrease in the mean oxide state of Mn resulted from the strong tendency of Ca2+ to segregate at the oxide surface [47], which was agreed with the results of XPS, H2-TPR and O2-TPD. In contrast, the CO2 yield of LMO was only approximately 60% above the T 90 temperature, while that of L8C2MO at the T 90 temperature was 6% higher than that of LMO, suggesting that Ca substitution enhanced the deep oxidation capacity of CB [7]. Importantly, compared with L8C2MO, L8C2MO-P exhibited a significantly greater CO2 yield (Fig. 5b), with a CO2 yield of approximately 95%, which was 29% greater than that of L8C2MO. Based on the production rates of CO2, the plasma-treated samples exhibited the highest conversion, indicating greater transformation of CB into the final products [48]. The redox ability of Mn4+/Mn3+ and active oxygen species both play significant roles in CB oxidation [24]. On the one hand, CB molecules adsorbed first on the Mn active sites with C-Cl bonding on Mn to form Mn-Cl or Mn-O-Cl, and then crack into different intermediate with released O* (O* denotes activated oxygen species) on the surface, in which the migration and activation of surface oxygen are implemented via oxygen vacancies (Vo). During this process, the adsorbed chlorine species will be rinsed from Mn sites also by O* via MnOx → MnOyClx/MnCl2 → MnOx circle [49]. On the other hand, oxygen from the gas phase can be activated by oxygen vacancies simultaneously with the oxidation of Mn3+ into Mn4+. In summary, suitable Mn4+/Mn3+ ratio implied the active capacity of the Mn-based catalyst which contributes mainly on CB degradation efficiency for LMO, while the additional surface adsorbed oxygen species and oxygen mobility will further attribute to the destruction capacity for intermediates for L8C2MO-P [50]. Hence, the high yield of CO2 on L8C2MO-P primarily resulted from the stability of the Mn active sites, which arose from the exposure of the Ca nanoparticles [51]. Ca species are believed to possess superior adsorption of Cl species, thereby inhibiting the erosion of Cl species on Mn and preserving its ability to migrate and activate surface oxygen [52]. Furthermore, plasma treatment provided a rich source of oxygen vacancies, inducing to a significant increase in the surface adsorption of oxygen by the catalyst, thereby the surface oxygen which has higher mobility than lattice oxygen can take part in the deep oxidation of the CB more actively [53]. In addition, the amount of inorganic chloride (HCl and Cl2) in the exhaust gas was measured to further investigate the mineralization ability of the as-prepared catalysts. As shown in Fig. 5c, the production rate of inorganic chlorine followed the trend L8C2MO-P > L8C2MO > LMO, and the L8C2MO-P evaluated by about 27% inorganic chlorine yields increased at its T 90 condition, which indicated that the formation/adsorption of inorganic chlorine tended to occur on the L8C2MO-P composition, while the removal of HCl on the Ca species surface was rapid; thus, deactivation owing to chlorine poisoning was slight. Since the industrial emissions of VOCs are generally with multicomponent pollutants and impurity interferences, the versatility of L8C2MO-P was evaluated toward different situations with a durability test. As shown in Fig. 5d, L8C2MO-P was first subjected to a 270 min aging at T 90 (350 °C), followed by the introduction of 10 vol.% H2O for 1 h, the CB conversion could maintain at ca. 92%. Interestingly, the injection of H2O had induced a slight increase in CB conversion, which could be ascribed to H2O molecules participate the reverse Deacon reaction or remove the chlorine from the catalyst surface [54] to prevent chlorine residue. In the next stage, the CB concentration was increased to 1 000 ppm, it could be observed that the CB conversion decreased slightly, after turning into 500 ppm of CB, the reaction activity recovered significantly. When the reaction temperature changed to 325 °C, a distinct decline in the CB conversion from ca. 90–83% was observed. However, on further elevating the temperature to 350 °C, the CB conversion efficiency could be mostly recovered. After that, the WHSV was reduced to 30 000 mL/(g·h), the reaction efficiency increased to ca. 93% obviously and then recovered when the WHSV was turned into 60 000 mL/(g·h), which may be a signal of external diffusion effect. Durability measurement results indicated that the L8C2MO-P sample can sustain H2O at elevated temperatures, and an optimum operation temperature for the industrial application of this catalyst is slight over its T 90 condition, which could be set above 350 °C. The organic byproduct of L8C2MO-P collected at 350 °C was detected via CG-MS (Figure S3), which revealed that a total of ten byproducts existed in the exhaust gas after CB oxidation, including isobutene, methylene chloride, hexane, acetic acid, phenol, hexanoic acid, methyl, isobutyl ketone, acetone, and hexanal ( Table 3), revealing the inconspicuous presence of polychlorinated aromatics and suggesting the absence of direct electrophilic chlorination on CB. In addition, the prominently detectable chlorinated organic material was CH2Cl2, with the majority of the remainder consisting of organic compounds such as alkanes, aldehydes, and acids, suggesting a relatively thorough inorganic transformation of chlorine species at this temperature, consistent with the Cl yield results. To investigate the reason behind the improved CO2 yield of the samples after plasma treatment, the catalytic agents were characterized using XPS to study the changes in surface species. In Fig. 6a, the binding energy of Mn 2p 3/2 for U-LMO shifted by 1.5 eV, indicating possible partial binding of Mn with Cl [12]. Upon Ca substitution, the binding energy shifted by only 0.4 eV, and plasma treatment did not cause an obvious shift, suggesting that Mn, predominantly L8C2MO-P, was sustained mainly in the oxidized state. In contrast, as shown in Fig. 6b, in comparison with that of L8C2MO, the binding energy center of Ca 2p for U-L8C2MO did not shift, aligning with the binding energy of CaO (346.6 eV) [28], while that for U-L8C2MO-P increased from 346.9 eV to 347.6 eV compared to that of L8C2MO-P, approaching the binding energy of CaCl2 (348 eV) [55]. Overall, the results suggested that Ca indeed plays an important role in protecting Mn activity by bonding with Cl, and plasma treatment can release more Ca to the surface, resulting in an increased abundance of the CaCl2 phase [31–35]; the route could be expressed in Eq. (6). As shown in Fig. 6c, the proportion of inorganic chlorine follows the trend L8C2MO-P > L8C2MO > LMO, where the notable increase in the inorganic chlorine proportions of L8C2MO and L8C2MO-P can be attributed to the increased ease of formation and subsequent desorption of Cl on the Ca species [12]. To further demonstrate the chlorine adsorption sites, the Raman spectra was also tested for the used samples. In Fig. 6d, the bands at 125 and 182 cm−1(CaCl2) [56,57], 336 cm−1 (LaOCl) [58] were observed for both U-L8C2MO and U-L8C2MO-P, which was not showed significant signals for U-LMO, which confirmed that Ca was the important sacrificed chlorination site for Ca participated catalysts. (6) CaCO 3 + MnCl x → CaCl 2 + CO 2 + Mn x + where Mn x + denotes Mn3+ or Mn4+. 3.3 Possible reaction route Fig. 7 shows the in situ DRIFTS spectra of CB adsorbed and oxidized on L8C2MO-P, L8C2MO and LMO at 300 °C. As presented in Fig. 7a, b and c, the CB adsorption situation, the bands observed for both samples at 1591 cm−1 and 1361 cm−1 originated from the CC stretching of absorbed CB molecules [2] and the stretching vibration of CO of the carboxylate groups of the acetate type [59], respectively. Moreover, bands at 1654 cm−1 corresponding to CC were detected for L8C2MO-P, and bands at 1632 cm−1 combined with the appearance of CC species were detected for L8C2MO, which were distinguished to the surface enolic species [60], and benzaldehyde (1271 cm−1) [61] can be well observed over LMO. The observation above illustrated that Cl can be removed from CB at Mn sites to form vinyl chloride (VC) [62] due to the enolic species and carboxylates were the predominant chemical adsorbed species on L8C2MO-P, L8C2MO. Furthermore, alcohol species (1124 cm−1) [27] were detected in the spectrum of L8C2MO-P, indicating its high CB adsorption ability. Moreover, the peak at 2364 cm−1 was observed in all the spectra, which represents the final product CO2, as well as the peak over 3100–3500 cm−1 was attributed to O–H from water as the final product of catalytic CB oxidation [59]. CB oxidation was carried out at different temperatures over LMO, L8C2MO and L8C2MO-P. For L8C2MO-P, as shown in Fig. 7d, enolic species and carboxylates were also identified based on the peaks at 1654 cm−1 and 1361 cm−1. Moreover, the bands at 2967 and 2872 cm−1 corresponded to the C–H stretching vibrations of CHn species from intermediate products [63]. This phenomenon indicated that enolic species aside by the desorption of Cl on the Ca site, and then the enolic species in combination with oxygen vacancies can be transformed readily into carboxylates. When elevated the reaction temperature, the bands corresponding to carboxylates became weaker, while the further oxidation products, such as alcohol species (1020, 1094 and 1173 cm−1) and acetic acid (1427 and 1483 cm−1) [64], increased in intensity. In brief, the following CB oxidation route was summarized as Scheme 1: CB → enolic species → carboxylate species → alcohol species → acetic acid → CO2. When CB oxidized on L8C2MO (Fig. 7e), at all temperatures, the bands at 1654 °C related to aldehyde species became very weak, and no bands related to carboxylate species were observed. With increasing temperature, the band appearing at 2667–2964 cm−1 over L8C2MO became strong, while that of L8C2MO-P became weak, indicating that the byproducts cannot be transformed over L8C2MO. Hence, compared with L8C2MO, L8C2MO-P exhibited a greater capacity to adsorb and activate with CB, especially in the deep oxidation of intermediate products of CB, owing to the adjacent chlorine adsorption by the exposure Ca species and abundant oxygen species caused by plasma treatment [64]. Subsequently, the new bands corresponding to the stretching vibrations of the benzyl alcohol (1124 cm−1) [65], and benzaldehyde (1271 cm−1) [63] can be well observed over LMO (Fig. 7f), which should be noted that the presence of alcohol and benzaldehyde gradually cumulated. 4 Conclusion In this work, we have been demonstrated that Ca species can be exsolved from La0.8Ca0.2MnO3 (L8C2MO) perovskite in just 15 min at room temperature after a 5% H2/Ar Plasma treatment, instead of much energy-consumption and time-consuming anneal reduction route under high temperature process, the plasma operation was shown successfully Ca species exposure and surface oxygen vacancies activation. Compared with L8C2MO, the plasma treated Ca containing sample L8C2MO-P exhibited better catalytic performance for CB destruction. Even though slightly weak ability (about 13 °C higher of T 90) than LMO, L8C2MO-P showed significantly promotion of mineralization efficiency (evaluated by about 29% CO2 increasing at each T 90 condition and 27% of inorganic chlorine yields). According to the characterizations, the superior performance on final products selectivity can be ascribed to the adjacent chlorination of exsolved Ca species, which is benefit to protect the active Mn site from chloride poison; and the same time, more oxygen vacancies that promoting abundant active oxygen species, is helpful to deep oxidation of the intermediate during CB degradation. The decomposition pathway of CB on L8C2MO-P was chlorobenzene → enolic species → carboxylate species → alcohol species → acetic acid → CO2. The study provides a rapid and broadening nanoparticle exsolution of plasma driven method and opens up new research directions for the catalyst poisoning inhabitation way to the combustion of CVOCs. coredata.dc:description: The degradation of chlorine-containing volatile organic compounds (CVOCs) catalytic combustion technology is subject to the catalyst chlorine poisoning, which is resulted from the chlorination of active phases, even though the structural stable perovskite. The reaction between Ca species and dissociated chlorine species is demonstrated as an efficient way to inhibited chlorine poisoning of the active phase. Herein, a Ca substituted partial La prepared La0.8Ca0.2MnO3 (named as L8C2MO) perovskite was treated by 5% H2/Ar plasma driven route (the treated sample was denoted as L8C2MO-P), which was applied for the chlorobenzene oxidation removal. The integrated characterization results of XRD, XPS, HRTEM, etc. confirmed that Ca (mainly exhibited as CaCO3) was successfully exsolved from La0.8Ca0.2MnO3 and simultaneously leaved oxygen vacancies on the surficial layers. The continuous catalytic oxidation experiments illustrated that the conversion efficiency of L8C2MO was unexpectedly decreased compared with that of LaMnO3 (LMO in short) sample, while that of L8C2MO-P was nearly maintained the oxidation capacity, with approximately 12 °C of 90% chlorobenzene conversion temperature (T 90) higher than that of LMO. Importantly, the CO2 and inorganic chlorine species yields were significantly enhanced for L8C2MO and L8C2MO-P. The characteristic of used samples showed a possible chlorinated Ca species formation while the status of Mn phases was hardly changed, suggesting the exsolved Ca could inhibit the poison of Mn sites by binding with dissociative chlorine species. Additionally, oxygen vacancies that generated along with Ca exsolution process was definitely contributed to the deep oxidation of chlorobenzene. The possible reaction route was also studied by in situ DRIFTS and GCMS. The work provides a potential route as in situ growth of adjacent sites to protect active phases from chlorine poison in CVOCs catalytic oxidation process.
coredata.dc:title: Plasma driven exsolution of Ca as the adjacent dechlorinated site in La0.8Ca0.2MnO3 perovskite: A highly mineralization chlorobenzene oxidation catalyst
